title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
added: *Robert Jervis, Francis Gavin, Joshua Rovner, and Diane N. Labrosse (eds.). 2018. ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.7312/jerv18834 Chaos in the Liberal Order: The Trump Presidency and International Politics in the Twenty-First Century]''. Columbia University Press.

*Jared McDonald and Sarah E. Croco, and Candace Turitto. 2019. "[https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/702234 Teflon Don or Politics as Usual? An Examination of Foreign Policy Flip-Flops in the Age of Trump]." ''Journal of Politics''.

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
deleted: In October 2017, the president announced a plan to achieve a record reduction in illegal immigration. Vice President Pence later described specific actions to be taken in those efforts, including the building of a southern border wall.<ref>[https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-vice-president-pence-u-s-immigration-customs-enforcement-employees/ "Remarks by Vice President Pence to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Employees"], Whitehouse, March 21, 2019</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
added: In late January 2020, the administration banned travel to the U.S. by Chinese nationals, allowing US citizens abroad and legal US residents to return.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tate|first=Curtis|title=Delta, American, United to suspend all China mainland flights as coronavirus crisis grows|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/2020/01/31/coronavirus-china-flight-ban-delta-cuts-all-flights-white-house/4620989002/|access-date=April 3, 2020|website=USA TODAY}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
added: On October 23, 2020, the [[Israel–Sudan normalization agreement]] was finalized between Israel and the [[Sudan]].

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
deleted: ''[[The Atlantic]]'' reported in 2020 that while on a visit to France, Trump had disparaged U.S. military personnel, including fallen soldiers, in crude and demeaning language; CNN and Fox News corroborated much of the reporting while Trump denied making the comments. The controversy only further strained his relations with the military.<ref name=StarrBrownn>Barbara Starr & Ryan Browne, [https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/07/politics/trump-attack-military-leadership/index.html Trump launches unprecedented attack on military leadership he appointed], CNN (September 8, 2020).</ref><ref>Tom Vanden Brook, Michael Collins & Deirdre Shesgreen, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/09/10/trumps-relations-military-further-strained-over-loser-remarks/5719981002/ Trump's tensions with the military grow after reports that he disparaged soldiers, generals], ''USA Today'' (September 10, 2020).</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the first Donald Trump administration
added: ''[[The Atlantic]]'' reported in 2020 that while on a visit to France, Trump had disparaged U.S. military personnel, including fallen soldiers, in crude and demeaning language; CNN and Fox News corroborated much of the reporting while Trump denied making the comments. The controversy only further strained his relations with the military.<ref name=StarrBrownn>Barbara Starr & Ryan Browne, [https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/07/politics/trump-attack-military-leadership/index.html Trump launches unprecedented attack on military leadership he appointed], CNN (September 8, 2020).</ref><ref>Tom Vanden Brook, Michael Collins & Deirdre Shesgreen, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/09/10/trumps-relations-military-further-strained-over-loser-remarks/5719981002/ Trump's tensions with the military grow after reports that he disparaged soldiers, generals], ''USA Today'' (September 10, 2020).</ref>
